io.github.dalayach.Print_tools

Class String_printer

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.github.dalayach.Print_tools.Helper_functions
      • io.github.dalayach.Print_tools.Build_strings
        • io.github.dalayach.Print_tools.String_printer
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Test_for_Helper_functions, TUTORIAL_RUN_ME

    public class String_printer
extends Build_strings
    This is the String_printer itself. This is the class to call if you wish to use the functions, and it will have all the functionality of Build_strings, but with some aliases included to keep code compact.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      String_printer()
      Creates a new String printer.

    • Method Detail

      • print_c

        public java.lang.String print_c(boolean borders,
                                int total,
                                java.lang.String... messages)
        Will print and return a sequence of Strings that is center-justified. Each will be separated with borders if the boolean parameter borders is true. This is an alias for print_center_justified().
        Parameters:
        borders - boolean that is true if borders are to be included, and false if not. Note that borders will add to the column width, so a sequence of Strings WITH borders will be longer than a sequence of Strings WITHOUT borders.
        total - int containing the expected size (given by the user, but we will check if it's correct)
        messages - sequence of Strings (or just a String array, depending how you wish to use it) that holds the data to be printed out as a String
        Returns:
        the newly created String that is now center-justified
        See Also:
        Build_strings.print_center_justified(boolean borders, int expected_size, String... messages)

      • print_c

        public java.lang.String print_c(int total,
                                java.lang.String... messages)
        Will print and return a sequence of Strings that is center-justified and separated by borders. This is an alias for print_center_justified().
        Parameters:
        total - int containing the expected size (given by the user, but we will check if it's correct)
        messages - sequence of Strings (or just a String array, depending how you wish to use it) that holds the data to be printed out as a String
        Returns:
        the newly created String that is now center-justified
        See Also:
        Build_strings.print_center_justified(boolean borders, int expected_size, String... messages)

      • println_c

        public java.lang.String println_c(boolean borders,
                                  int total,
                                  java.lang.String... messages)
        Will print and return a sequence of Strings that is center-justified, followed by a newline character. Each will be separated with borders if the boolean parameter borders is true. The newline character at the end of the returned String will allow for cleaner code, especially when looping. This is an alias for print_center_justified().
        Parameters:
        borders - boolean that is true if borders are to be included, and false if not. Note that borders will add to the column width, so a sequence of Strings WITH borders will be longer than a sequence of Strings WITHOUT borders.
        total - int containing the expected size (given by the user, but we will check if it's correct)
        messages - sequence of Strings (or just a String array, depending how you wish to use it) that holds the data to be printed out as a String
        Returns:
        the newly created String that is now center-justified, followed by a newline character
        See Also:
        Build_strings.print_center_justified(boolean borders, int expected_size, String... messages)

      • println_c

        public java.lang.String println_c(int total,
                                  java.lang.String... messages)
        Will print and return a sequence of Strings that is center-justified, followed by a newline character, and separated by borders. Will include a newline character at the end of the returned String, allowing for cleaner code, especially when looping. This is an alias for print_center_justified().
        Parameters:
        total - int containing the expected size (given by the user, but we will check if it's correct)
        messages - sequence of Strings (or just a String array, depending how you wish to use it) that holds the data to be printed out as a String
        Returns:
        the newly created String that is now center-justified, followed by a newline character
        See Also:
        Build_strings.print_center_justified(boolean borders, int expected_size, String... messages)

      • print_l

        public java.lang.String print_l(boolean borders,
                                int total,
                                java.lang.String... messages)
        Will print and return a sequence of Strings that is left-justified. Each will be separated with borders if the boolean parameter borders is true. This is an alias for print_left_justified().
        Parameters:
        borders - boolean that is true if borders are to be included, and false if not. Note that borders will add to the column width, so a sequence of Strings WITH borders will be longer than a sequence of Strings WITHOUT borders.
        total - int containing the expected size (given by the user, but we will check if it's correct)
        messages - sequence of Strings (or just a String array, depending how you wish to use it) that holds the data to be printed out as a String
        Returns:
        the newly created String that is now left-justified
        See Also:
        Build_strings.print_left_justified(boolean borders, int expected_size, String... messages)

      • print_l

        public java.lang.String print_l(int total,

      • println_l

        public java.lang.String println_l(boolean borders,
                                  int total,
                                  java.lang.String... messages)
        Will print and return a sequence of Strings that is left-justified, followed by a newline character. Each will be separated with borders if the boolean parameter borders is true. Will include a newline character at the end of the returned String, allowing for cleaner code, especially when looping. This is an alias for print_left_justified().
        Parameters:
        borders - boolean that is true if borders are to be included, and false if not. Note that borders will add to the column width, so a sequence of Strings WITH borders will be longer than a sequence of Strings WITHOUT borders.
        total - int containing the expected size (given by the user, but we will check if it's correct)
        messages - sequence of Strings (or just a String array, depending how you wish to use it) that holds the data to be printed out as a String
        Returns:
        the newly created String that is now left-justified, followed by a newline character
        See Also:
        Build_strings.print_left_justified(boolean borders, int expected_size, String... messages)

      • println_l

        public java.lang.String println_l(int total,
                                  java.lang.String... messages)
        Will print and return a sequence of Strings that is left-justified, followed by a newline character, and separated by borders. Will include a newline character at the end of the returned String, allowing for cleaner code, especially when looping. This is an alias for print_left_justified().
        Parameters:
        total - int containing the expected size (given by the user, but we will check if it's correct)
        messages - sequence of Strings (or just a String array, depending how you wish to use it) that holds the data to be printed out as a String
        Returns:
        the newly created String that is now left-justified, followed by a newline character
        See Also:
        Build_strings.print_left_justified(boolean borders, int expected_size, String... messages)

        messages - sequence of Strings (or just a String array, depending how you wish to use it) that holds the data to be printed out as a String

        public java.lang.String print_r(int total,

      • println_r

        public java.lang.String println_r(boolean borders,
                                  int total,
                                  java.lang.String... messages)
        Will print and return a sequence of Strings that is right-justified, followed by a newline character. Each will be separated with borders if the boolean parameter borders is true. Will include a newline character at the end of the returned String, allowing for cleaner code, especially when looping. This is an alias for print_right_justified().
        Parameters:
        borders - boolean that is true if borders are to be included, and false if not. Note that borders will add to the column width, so a sequence of Strings WITH borders will be longer than a sequence of Strings WITHOUT borders.
        total - int containing the expected size (given by the user, but we will check if it's correct)
        messages - sequence of Strings (or just a String array, depending how you wish to use it) that holds the data to be printed out as a String
        Returns:
        the newly created String that is now right-justified, followed by a newline character
        See Also:
        Build_strings.print_right_justified(boolean borders, int expected_size, String... messages)
